Award.AwardTitle: Diversity and Climate Change: using elevational gradients to uncover processes underlying mammalian species distributions
Award.AbstractNarration:
Rapid rates of extinction resulting from habitat destruction, resource exploitation, and climate change lend an unprecedented urgency to documenting and understanding biological diversity. Furthermore, effective conservation efforts will require a better comprehension of the mechanisms creating and maintaining biodiversity. Small mammal distributions will be examined on two contrasting montane gradients in the Southern Rocky Mountains, the San Juans and the Front Range, to test hypotheses related to the maintenance of biological diversity and to detect range shifts due to climate change. Three elevational transects within each mountain range will be surveyed to document diversity, species distributions, population trends, climate, food resources, and habitat characteristics. Comparisons between current ranges and historical distributions at a landscape scale will determine the degree of range shifts associated with documented climate changes.

Knowledge of the interrelated processes structuring small mammal communities will serve as a foundation for understanding biodiversity patterns and their protection, and it will illustrate human impacts on species distributions in montane systems. Broader impacts of this project will include integration of the research into a science education program for under-represented grade school girls, participation in the San Juan Initiative to incorporate young people of Latin and Native American descent into science, and active recruitment of under-represented students into the research. The project will aid in the training of young scientists and involve active participation of undergraduates enrolled in the PI's classes. Additionally, a data repository and an education-outreach website will be used to disseminate research findings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objectives of this study were to use mammal distributions on two contrasting elevational gradients in the CO Rocky Mountains (The Front Range and the San Juan Mountains) to test what factors are driving trends in biodiversity. It is clear from our previous work that climate—a combination of temperature and precipitation—is critical but we are testing whether that association to mammals is physiological or an interaction between climate and quantity of food resources. This is important to improve our understanding of biodiversity and our conservation efforts. But additionally, determining the direct effects of climate and the indirect effects through food resources has critical implications for how mammals may respond to climate change alone or in combination with climate change impacts on their main food supply.  Elevational gradients hold enormous potential for understanding biodiversity since variation in climate and species richness are on the same order of magnitude as other ecological gradients (e.g., latitude), but occur over much smaller spatial scales with contrasting patterns such that the patterns can be replicated and stronger results achieved. Over a three–year period, two elevational transects within each mountain range at 32 individual study sites (see Figure 1) were surveyed to document the number of species, each species’ distribution and population sizes, climate, food resources, and habitat characteristics. We have detected 58 mammal species using 6043 captures (see Figure 2) and 1187 voucher specimens; 1920 vegetation surveys; 2500 arthropod samples from 840 pitfalls; and 3 years of air & soil temperatures and precipitation levels. We also built a database of all previous localities of each mammal species in the state of Colorado as well as in each of the two mountain ranges using 57,184 historical mammal records. From this database, we were able to calculate the historical distribution of each species pre-climate change impacts. These multiple sets of data are being used to robustly and simultaneously test the main ecological theories of diversity including temperature, precipitation, productivity, area, mid-domain effect, habitat heterogeneity, and food resources, and competitive interactions. Comparisons between current ranges and historical distributions are being used to determine the degree of range shifts due to documented climate changes in temperature and precipitation.

Mentoring and training included 1 post-doctoral associate, 4 graduate students, and 16 undergraduates of which 2 were minorities and more than half were female (see Mentoring photo). Graduate and undergraduates students have been involved in study design, data gathering, conference presentations, and manuscripts submitted and in preparation. One graduate student’s dissertation is based on this study. Five undergraduate honors theses were produced, including one by a minority student. The results have been disseminated to the scientific communities through 15 conference presentations, 7 departmental seminars, and 3 journal articles with many more journal articles to follow. Results have been disseminated to local resources managers, particularly at Rocky Mountain National Park, National Forest and BLM managers through yearly reports, 5 public talks, and 2 training experiences. College students have been exposed to the research through direct research experiences in the field and lab. Additionally, the research was included in university class content for Mammalogy, Field Methods in Zoology & Botany, and a newly developed class on Mountain Ecology & Conservation. High school and grade school children were reached through multiple lectures, a public talk, and participation in the Rocky Mountain biobliz and the GAMES museum program.
